instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has green light, fan spin, big coils have voltage, CPU gets hot, but i get no usb activity.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Post CPU core voltage?
When board boots, it should drop from 1.15V to 0.75V.
Beeps RAM error when RAM is removed?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Tks.

No RAM beep when removed.

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL>/2/3 sometimes starts at 1.15VAND drops to 7.5v, but them oscilates bettwen 7.5 and 0.5V. 

Other times, they oscilates bettwen 1.15V and 0.144V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
As far as I know, 7.5V is bigger than 1.15V.
And I'm pretty sure you've never got 7.5V at CPU core.
BTW, ALWAYS check DC voltage on the output pin of the coil, where the filter cap is connected.

Stable voltage at L7630?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,

Sorry, you're right. I had bad batteries on multimeter.

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL>/2/3 starts at 1.15V AND drops to 0.75V steady.

L7630 has stable voltages. 1.25V on pin1 and 1V on pin2

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
No need to check L7630, if already got correct VCORE.
Looks like your board boots and should get USB activity, or external image.
If not, there should be a GPU problem, which blocks the CPU after booted.

Easy to disable GPU on this board, to confirm the problem.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,
I have no USB activity nither external image.
I disabled external GPU with medusa, but still no usb activity.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: Did you remove one of <RESISTOR>R8904</RESISTOR>/11 too?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: No i dindn't. Shall i remove them?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: OK, now i've removed <RESISTOR>R8911</RESISTOR> and now i have usb activity. Is there other any way to solve this problem, without disabling / replacing the GPU?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: Now you have to flash BIOS again, to disable GPU...
